canonical_explanation.text: India has many famous historical monuments that tell us about our rich history and culture. The Taj Mahal in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal. It is made of white marble and is one of the Seven Wonders of the World. The Red Fort (Lal Qila) in Delhi was built by Shah Jahan and is made of red sandstone. Every year on Independence Day (15th August), the Prime Minister hoists the national flag at the Red Fort. The Qutub Minar in Delhi is one of the tallest brick minarets in the world, built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak. The Konark Sun Temple in Odisha was built by King Narasimhadeva I and is shaped like a giant chariot of the Sun God with huge stone wheels. The Ajanta Caves in Maharashtra are ancient rock-cut caves with beautiful paintings and sculptures of Buddha. These caves are over 2,000 years old. These monuments are part of our national heritage. Heritage means things of value passed down from the past. We must preserve and protect our monuments by not littering, not writing on walls, and following rules when visiting them. Many Indian monuments are UNESCO World Heritage Sites, which means the whole world recognises their importance.
rules: The Taj Mahal was built by Shah Jahan in Agra, made of white marble
The Red Fort was built by Shah Jahan in Delhi, made of red sandstone
The PM hoists the national flag at the Red Fort on Independence Day
The Qutub Minar in Delhi was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak
The Konark Sun Temple in Odisha is shaped like a chariot of the Sun God
The Ajanta Caves in Maharashtra have ancient paintings of Buddha
Heritage means valuable things passed down from the past
We must protect monuments by not littering or damaging them
Many Indian monuments are UNESCO World Heritage Sites

questions.question_text: Who built the Taj Mahal?
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. He built it in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. It took about 20 years and 20,000 workers to build it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Akbar, Ashoka, and Aurangzeb did not build the Taj Mahal. It was built by Shah Jahan as a memorial for his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

questions.question_text: In which city is the Taj Mahal located?
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is located in the city of Agra in Uttar Pradesh. It stands on the banks of the river Yamuna. Millions of tourists from all over the world visit Agra to see the Taj Mahal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal is not in Delhi, Jaipur, or Lucknow. It is in the city of Agra, Uttar Pradesh, on the banks of the Yamuna river.

questions.question_text: The Taj Mahal is made of which material?
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is made of beautiful white marble. The marble was brought from Rajasthan. The white marble makes the Taj Mahal shine brilliantly, especially in moonlight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red sandstone was used for the Red Fort, not the Taj Mahal. The Taj Mahal is specifically made of white marble, which gives it its famous glowing white appearance.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Taj Mahal was built in memory of Mumtaz Mahal.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal after she died. The name 'Taj Mahal' is believed to come from Mumtaz Mahal's name.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Shah Jahan did build the Taj Mahal in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal. It is one of the most famous symbols of love in the world.

questions.question_text: The Taj Mahal is considered one of the Seven Wonders of the World. Why do you think it is so special?

options.text: Because it is the tallest building in India
Because of its beautiful white marble architecture and the love story behind it
Because it is the oldest building in the world
Because it was built in just one day

questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is special because of its stunning beauty — its white marble, intricate carvings, and perfect design. It is also famous for the love story of Shah Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal. It took about 20 years to build, not one day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal is not the tallest or oldest building. It was not built in a day — it took about 20 years. It is famous for its breathtaking white marble beauty and the love story behind it.

questions.question_text: The Red Fort in Delhi is made of which material?
questions.explanation_correct: The Red Fort (Lal Qila) is made of red sandstone. That is why it is called the 'Red' Fort — because of the reddish colour of the sandstone used to build its massive walls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: White marble was used for the Taj Mahal, not the Red Fort. The Red Fort gets its name from the red sandstone used in its construction.

questions.question_text: Who built the Red Fort in Delhi?
questions.explanation_correct: The Red Fort was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in the 17th century. The same emperor also built the Taj Mahal. The Red Fort served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Qutub-ud-din Aibak built the Qutub Minar, not the Red Fort. Ashoka and Akbar built other monuments. Shah Jahan built both the Red Fort and the Taj Mahal.

questions.question_text: What happens at the Red Fort every Independence Day?

options.text: The Prime Minister hoists the national flag
A big market is set up
The fort is closed for everyone

questions.explanation_correct: Every year on 15th August (Independence Day), the Prime Minister of India hoists the national flag (tiranga) at the Red Fort and addresses the nation. This tradition started in 1947 when India became independent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Red Fort is not used for cricket or a market on Independence Day. It is not closed. The Prime Minister hoists the national flag there every 15th August and gives a speech to the nation.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Red Fort is called 'Lal Qila' because 'lal' means red in Hindi.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. 'Lal' means red in Hindi and 'Qila' means fort. The Red Fort is called Lal Qila because its walls are made of red sandstone, giving it a beautiful reddish colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. 'Lal' indeed means red in Hindi. The fort's massive walls are made of red sandstone, which is why it earned the name Lal Qila (Red Fort).

questions.question_text: Shah Jahan built two famous monuments. They are:

options.text: Qutub Minar and Konark Sun Temple

questions.explanation_correct: Shah Jahan built both the Taj Mahal (in Agra) and the Red Fort (in Delhi). The Taj Mahal is made of white marble and the Red Fort is made of red sandstone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak. The Konark Sun Temple was built by King Narasimhadeva I. The Ajanta Caves are ancient caves, not built by Shah Jahan. Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal and Red Fort.

questions.question_text: Where is the Qutub Minar located?
questions.explanation_correct: The Qutub Minar is located in Delhi (specifically in the Mehrauli area of South Delhi). It is one of the tallest brick minarets in the world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar is not in Mumbai, Agra, or Jaipur. It is located in Delhi and is a famous landmark of the city.

questions.question_text: Who started building the Qutub Minar?
questions.explanation_correct: The Qutub Minar was started by Qutub-ud-din Aibak, who was the first Sultan of Delhi. Later rulers completed the remaining floors. The minar is named after him.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal and Red Fort. Akbar built Fatehpur Sikri. Ashoka built pillars and stupas. The Qutub Minar was started by Qutub-ud-din Aibak.

questions.question_text: The Qutub Minar is famous because it is one of the:

options.text: Tallest brick minarets in the world

questions.explanation_correct: The Qutub Minar is one of the tallest brick minarets (towers) in the world. It stands about 73 metres tall and has 5 storeys. It is made of red sandstone and marble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar is not a church, bridge, or cave. It is a tall tower (minaret) and is one of the tallest brick minarets in the world at about 73 metres.

questions.question_text: The Konark Sun Temple is located in which state?
questions.explanation_correct: The Konark Sun Temple is located in the state of Odisha, in eastern India. It was built in the 13th century and is dedicated to the Sun God, Surya.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Konark Sun Temple is not in Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, or Gujarat. It is in Odisha on the eastern coast of India.

questions.question_text: The Konark Sun Temple is shaped like a:
questions.explanation_correct: The Konark Sun Temple is shaped like a giant chariot of the Sun God (Surya). It has 24 beautifully carved stone wheels and is pulled by 7 stone horses. The wheels also work as sundials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Konark Sun Temple is not shaped like a pyramid, dome, or ship. It is uniquely designed to look like a giant chariot with 24 stone wheels and 7 horses.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Konark Sun Temple was built by King Narasimhadeva I.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Konark Sun Temple was built by King Narasimhadeva I of the Eastern Ganga Dynasty in the 13th century. It is dedicated to the Sun God.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. King Narasimhadeva I did build the Konark Sun Temple in Odisha as a tribute to the Sun God.

questions.question_text: The Konark Sun Temple has 24 stone wheels. Some people say these wheels represent the 24 hours of a day. What does this tell us about the builders?

options.text: They did not know how to count
They were very skilled and knew about time and astronomy
They built too many wheels by mistake

questions.explanation_correct: The 24 wheels of the Konark Sun Temple show that the ancient builders were very skilled and had knowledge of time and astronomy. The wheels can also be used as sundials to tell the time of day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 24 wheels were not a mistake or random. The builders were highly skilled people who built the wheels to represent the 24 hours of the day and even designed them to work as sundials.

questions.question_text: Where are the Ajanta Caves located?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ajanta Caves are located in the state of Maharashtra, near the city of Aurangabad. They are ancient rock-cut caves carved into a hillside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ajanta Caves are not in Kerala, Karnataka, or Madhya Pradesh. They are in Maharashtra, cut into the rocky hills near Aurangabad.

questions.question_text: What are the Ajanta Caves famous for?

options.text: Beautiful ancient paintings and sculptures of Buddha

questions.explanation_correct: The Ajanta Caves are famous for their beautiful ancient paintings and sculptures related to Buddha and Buddhism. The paintings on the cave walls are over 2,000 years old and show scenes from Buddha's life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ajanta Caves do not have gold mines, underground rivers, or dinosaur bones. They are famous for their stunning ancient paintings and sculptures depicting Buddha and his teachings.

questions.question_text: How old are the Ajanta Caves approximately?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ajanta Caves are over 2,000 years old. They were carved and painted between the 2nd century BCE and the 5th century CE. This makes them some of the oldest art in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ajanta Caves are not 50, 100, or 500 years old. They are over 2,000 years old, making them one of the most ancient examples of Indian art and architecture.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Ajanta Caves were carved out of rock on a hillside.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Ajanta Caves are rock-cut caves, which means they were carved directly out of the rocky hillside. Workers chiseled and carved the rock to create rooms, pillars, and sculptures inside the hill.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The Ajanta Caves are indeed rock-cut caves carved out of the hillside, not built with bricks or other materials.

questions.question_text: What does 'heritage' mean?

options.text: Valuable things passed down from the past

questions.explanation_correct: Heritage means valuable things that are passed down from past generations. This includes monuments, traditions, art, music, and customs. Our heritage tells us about our history and culture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heritage is not something new, a food, or a modern building. It refers to valuable things from the past — buildings, traditions, art, and culture — that we inherit from our ancestors.

questions.question_text: Why should we protect historical monuments?

options.text: They tell us about our history and culture
So we can rebuild them differently

questions.explanation_correct: Historical monuments tell us about our rich history, culture, and the skills of people who lived long ago. Once a monument is damaged, it cannot be replaced. Protecting them ensures future generations can learn from them too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monuments should not be sold or rebuilt differently. They are very important, not unimportant. We protect them because they are irreplaceable pieces of our history that teach us about our past.

questions.question_text: When visiting a monument, which of these actions is WRONG?

options.text: Writing your name on the walls

questions.explanation_correct: Writing your name on the walls of a monument is wrong and damages the monument. We should never scratch, write on, or deface historical monuments. Taking photographs, reading information, and following rules are all good behaviours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Taking photographs, reading information boards, and following rules are all correct behaviours when visiting a monument. Writing on walls is the wrong action as it damages our precious heritage.

questions.question_text: What does UNESCO World Heritage Site mean?

options.text: A site that only Indians can visit
A site recognised by the world as very important and valuable
A site that is new and modern

questions.explanation_correct: A UNESCO World Heritage Site is a place recognised by the whole world as very important and valuable. UNESCO is an international organisation that helps protect these special places. Many Indian monuments are UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
questions.explanation_incorrect: UNESCO sites are not only for Indians, nor are they new or playgrounds. They are places of outstanding cultural or natural importance that the whole world agrees must be preserved.

questions.question_text: Sita visited a monument on the banks of the Yamuna river. It was made of white marble and looked beautiful in the moonlight. Which monument did she visit?
questions.explanation_correct: Sita visited the Taj Mahal. The clues are: it is on the banks of the Yamuna river, made of white marble, and looks beautiful in moonlight. All these describe the Taj Mahal in Agra.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Red Fort is made of red sandstone, not white marble. The Qutub Minar is a tower, not on the Yamuna. The Konark Sun Temple is in Odisha. The monument on the Yamuna made of white marble is the Taj Mahal.

questions.question_text: On 15th August, Raj watches the Prime Minister on TV giving a speech from a famous fort. Which fort is it?
questions.explanation_correct: The Prime Minister gives a speech from the Red Fort in Delhi on 15th August (Independence Day). This tradition began in 1947 when Jawaharlal Nehru, the first PM, hoisted the flag there after independence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Amber Fort, Golconda Fort, and Agra Fort are all important forts, the Independence Day flag hoisting ceremony takes place at the Red Fort in Delhi.

questions.question_text: Meera sees a very tall tower made of red sandstone in Delhi. Her teacher says it was built by the first Sultan of Delhi. Which monument is it?
questions.explanation_correct: Meera is looking at the Qutub Minar. The clues are: tall tower, red sandstone, in Delhi, built by the first Sultan of Delhi (Qutub-ud-din Aibak). All these describe the Qutub Minar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Red Fort is a fort, not a tower. India Gate and Lotus Temple are modern landmarks. The tall tower in Delhi built by the first Sultan is the Qutub Minar.

questions.question_text: The Konark Sun Temple has __________ stone wheels carved on it.
questions.explanation_correct: The Konark Sun Temple has 24 beautifully carved stone wheels. These are said to represent the 24 hours of a day. The temple is designed as a chariot of the Sun God with these wheels and 7 horses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number is not 12, 36, or 48. The Konark Sun Temple has exactly 24 stone wheels, believed to represent the 24 hours of the day.

questions.question_text: The paintings in the Ajanta Caves have survived for over 2,000 years. What does this tell us about the artists who made them?

options.text: They were very skilled and used excellent natural materials

questions.explanation_correct: The fact that the Ajanta paintings have lasted over 2,000 years shows that the ancient artists were incredibly skilled. They used natural colours from minerals and plants that have stood the test of time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The artists did not use modern paints — they used natural colours. The paintings lasting 2,000 years proves great skill, not lack of it. They were painted thousands of years ago, not yesterday.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a way to protect monuments?

options.text: Not scratching or writing on walls
Breaking pieces to take home as souvenirs
Following the rules at the site

questions.explanation_correct: Breaking pieces to take home is NOT a way to protect monuments — it is a way to damage them! We must never take pieces of monuments. We should keep them clean, not write on walls, and follow rules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not littering, not writing on walls, and following rules are all good ways to protect monuments. Breaking pieces to take home is harmful and illegal.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the Taj Mahal is CORRECT?

options.text: It was built by Akbar in Delhi
It was built by Shah Jahan in Agra using white marble
It was built by Ashoka in Patna
It was built by the British in Kolkata

questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in Agra, Uttar Pradesh. It is made of white marble and was built in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal was not built by Akbar, Ashoka, or the British. It was not in Delhi, Patna, or Kolkata. It was built by Shah Jahan in Agra using white marble.

questions.question_text: The Qutub Minar has approximately how many storeys?
questions.explanation_correct: The Qutub Minar has 5 storeys. It stands about 73 metres tall and is made of red sandstone and marble. Each storey has a balcony that goes around the tower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar does not have 3, 10, or 15 storeys. It has 5 storeys, each marked by a projecting balcony.

questions.question_text: The Konark Sun Temple is dedicated to which god?
questions.explanation_correct: The Konark Sun Temple is dedicated to the Sun God (Surya). The entire temple is designed as a chariot of the Sun God, with 24 wheels and 7 horses pulling it across the sky.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Konark Sun Temple is not dedicated to Shiva, Vishnu, or Ganesha. It is specifically dedicated to the Sun God (Surya), which is why it is called the Sun Temple.

questions.question_text: The Ajanta Caves are important examples of which type of architecture?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ajanta Caves are important examples of ancient rock-cut architecture. They were carved directly out of the rocky hillside, not built with bricks or other materials. This shows the amazing skill of ancient Indian builders.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ajanta Caves are not modern buildings, wooden houses, or brick temples. They are ancient rock-cut caves, carved out of a hillside over 2,000 years ago.

questions.question_text: The Red Fort is also known as __________ in Hindi.
questions.explanation_correct: The Red Fort is called 'Lal Qila' in Hindi. 'Lal' means red and 'Qila' means fort. It gets this name because its massive walls are made of red sandstone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hawa Mahal is in Jaipur. 'Safed Mahal' means White Palace and 'Neela Ghar' means Blue House — these are not names for the Red Fort. The Red Fort is called Lal Qila in Hindi.

questions.question_text: Your school is organising a trip to a monument. Which of these should you do?

options.text: Carve your name on the stones
Listen to the guide and learn about its history
Touch and climb on the delicate carvings

questions.explanation_correct: When visiting a monument, you should listen to guides, learn about its history, and follow rules. You should never throw litter, carve names, or touch delicate carvings as these actions damage the monument.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing litter, carving names, and climbing on carvings all damage monuments. The right thing to do is listen to the guide, learn about the history, and treat the monument with respect.

questions.question_text: Which monument is NOT in Delhi?
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is NOT in Delhi — it is in Agra, Uttar Pradesh. The Red Fort, Qutub Minar, and India Gate are all located in Delhi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Red Fort, Qutub Minar, and India Gate are all in Delhi. The Taj Mahal is the one that is not in Delhi — it is in Agra.

questions.question_text: Why do you think the Konark Sun Temple was built with 7 horses pulling the chariot?

options.text: Because 7 horses represent the 7 days of the week
Because there were only 7 horses available

questions.explanation_correct: The 7 horses of the Konark Sun Temple are believed to represent the 7 days of the week. Just as the 24 wheels represent the 24 hours, the 7 horses show the builders' knowledge of time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 7 horses were not random or because of availability. They represent the 7 days of the week, showing the ancient builders' understanding of time and astronomy.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Qutub Minar, Konark Sun Temple, and Ajanta Caves are all UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. All five of these monuments — Taj Mahal, Red Fort, Qutub Minar, Konark Sun Temple, and Ajanta Caves — are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. This means the whole world recognises their importance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. All these five monuments are indeed UNESCO World Heritage Sites, recognised internationally for their cultural significance.

questions.question_text: Which two monuments were built by the same ruler?

options.text: Taj Mahal and Konark Sun Temple

questions.explanation_correct: Both the Red Fort and the Taj Mahal were built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. The Red Fort is in Delhi and made of red sandstone, while the Taj Mahal is in Agra and made of white marble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar was built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak (not Shah Jahan). The Konark Sun Temple was built by King Narasimhadeva I. The Ajanta Caves were carved by ancient monks. Only the Red Fort and Taj Mahal were both built by Shah Jahan.

questions.question_text: The paintings in the Ajanta Caves mostly show scenes from the life of:
questions.explanation_correct: The paintings in the Ajanta Caves mostly show scenes from the life of Lord Buddha and stories from Buddhist texts called Jataka tales. These paintings are some of the finest examples of ancient Indian art.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ajanta Caves are not about Mughal kings, British rulers, or Greek warriors. They are Buddhist caves with paintings and sculptures showing scenes from Lord Buddha's life and Jataka tales.

questions.question_text: If you were standing at the top of the Qutub Minar, approximately how high above the ground would you be?
questions.explanation_correct: The Qutub Minar is about 73 metres tall — that is taller than a 20-storey building! It is one of the tallest brick minarets in the world and a remarkable achievement of ancient architecture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Qutub Minar is not 10, 30, or 200 metres tall. It stands at approximately 73 metres, making it one of the tallest brick structures in the world.

questions.question_text: The Taj Mahal stands on the banks of the river __________.
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal stands on the banks of the river Yamuna in Agra. The view of the Taj Mahal from across the Yamuna is one of the most famous views in the world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal is not on the Ganga, Narmada, or Godavari. It stands on the banks of the Yamuna river in Agra, Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question_text: Which organisation recognises and helps protect World Heritage Sites?
questions.explanation_correct: UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation) recognises and helps protect World Heritage Sites around the world. India has many UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NASA studies space. WHO deals with health. UNICEF helps children. UNESCO is the organisation that identifies and helps protect World Heritage Sites.

questions.question_text: The Taj Mahal is one of the Seven Wonders of the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Taj Mahal is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World (modern world). It was chosen through a worldwide vote. People from all over the world voted for it because of its beauty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World included pyramids and other structures. The Taj Mahal is part of the New Seven Wonders of the (Modern) World.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Qutub Minar is made of red sandstone and marble.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Qutub Minar is built using red sandstone and marble. The first three storeys are mainly red sandstone, while the fourth and fifth storeys use marble and sandstone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The Qutub Minar does use both red sandstone and marble in its construction.

questions.question_text: Amit's grandmother says, 'Our monuments are like treasure chests of our past.' What does she mean?

options.text: Monuments have gold hidden inside them
Monuments store valuable information about our history and culture
Monuments should be dug up to find treasure

questions.explanation_correct: Grandmother means that monuments hold valuable information about our history, culture, and the people who lived before us. Just like a treasure chest holds precious things, monuments hold precious knowledge of our past.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monuments do not have gold hidden inside, are not made of treasure, and should not be dug up. The grandmother means that monuments are valuable because they hold information about our rich history.

questions.question_text: Which monument is in the state of Odisha?
questions.explanation_correct: The Konark Sun Temple is in the state of Odisha, on the eastern coast of India. The Taj Mahal is in Uttar Pradesh, the Red Fort is in Delhi, and the Ajanta Caves are in Maharashtra.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal is in Uttar Pradesh. The Red Fort is in Delhi. The Ajanta Caves are in Maharashtra. Only the Konark Sun Temple is in Odisha.

questions.question_text: Which is the OLDEST among these monuments?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ajanta Caves are the oldest, being over 2,000 years old. The Qutub Minar is about 800 years old. The Taj Mahal and Red Fort are both about 400 years old, built in the 17th century by Shah Jahan.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Taj Mahal and Red Fort are about 400 years old. The Qutub Minar is about 800 years old. The Ajanta Caves, at over 2,000 years old, are the oldest among these monuments.
